text: We will hear arguments next in Number 72-5830, Patterson against Warner.
May it please the Court.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Well you haven’t filed a suggestion of mootness, have you?
No, Your Honor, I haven’t.
But this is the usual procedure before you argue?

Yes, Your Honor, my original -- I was requested to respond to suggestion of mootness on behalf of a counsel for the appellant, so I would assume now that the motion is before the Court that I could change my position and argue that yes, it is moot.
Well, a normal procedure is that you file a suggestion of mootness.
Yes, Your Honor, I think normal procedure is that the appellee --
When did you change your mind, just now?
No, Your Honor, within the last quite frankly though, within the last several weeks.
Well, if you’re right, can we decide the question of mootness here, or would we have to vacate? In remand of this three-judge district was a three-judge court wasn’t it?
Yes.
District Court will let them decide whether there’s question of mootness, because under this being a federal case -- by where it’s moot, but we do is wipe the slate clean all the way down.
Yes, Your Honor, I’m not -- quite frankly, I’m not sure what this Court can do -- as to decide whether it is moot or rather remand it to the District Court.
Well, I must say, I have difficulty in light of your retroactivity question that both of you raised.

Well, if you let me continue Justice Brennan, Justice Cardozo in answer to whether state decisions are retroactive or not, said and that a state may make a choice for itself between the principle of forward operation and the relation backwards.
Well in the first instance, isn’t it primarily the business of West Virginia courts to decide the retroactivity matter anyway?
Yes, Your Honor.
And you said they have decided it back in 1902 -- the general preposition.
Yes, Your Honor, so therefore -- so what I’m saying is that Reece versus Geis does apply to Patterson.
Do you mean that everybody that’s had a judgment against them with the JP court from 1900 to date is entitled to get his money back?
As well as I can interpret that case, Your Honor, yes.
There’s nothing to choose, except so far relates to mootness.
I don’t understand Justice Douglas, what --
Very well, if you don’t understand, it’s too late.[Laughter]
Well, what if it is retroactive so that you can’t let the execution on this judgment.
Well, now that’s my next argument in support of mootness.
